Award.AwardTitle: Promoting diversity and community college transfer success in the biology and biochemistry curricula

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Augustana College offers scholarships to students of color or community college transfer students who are majoring in biology or biochemistry. Funding for 20 scholars is targeted to increase the number of underrepresented minority majors at the college to at least 8 per year and the number of community college transfer students to 10, at least 85% of whom will graduate. All of the scholars participate in a project to annotate the genome of the bacterium Meiothermus ruber, authentic research on a project initiated by the PI and funded through the Department of Energy. They are also supported by enhanced tutoring, advising, and other measures to ease the transition to Augustana, along with a summer bridging program, a first-year learning community, and interaction with students at other institutions. In this way a series of high-impact teaching practices used throughout the biology curriculum fosters intellectual development of the students, while promoting communication between students and faculty in Biology and Chemistry Departments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project created the Augustana College Science Scholars (ACSS) program, which financially supported thirty-six students for one or more academic terms as they worked toward undergraduate degrees in various STEM fields. An emphasis was placed on recruiting students of color and community college transfer students who planned to major in biology or biochemistry. However, the program accepted qualified students interested in other STEM fields. For example, majors in math, chemistry, physics, and geology were represented in this group. It is projected that eighty-six percent of the students who received S-STEM scholarships through the ACSS program will successfully graduate from Augustana with an undergraduate degree in a STEM field. All ACSS graduates attained the degree within four years of enrollment at the college.

The ACSS program benefited by developing alongside institutional initiatives to increase minority student and transfer student recruitment and retention. Minority student enrollment at Augustana increased fifteen percent over the funding period. Thirty percent of ACSS participants were students of color and nineteen percent were transfer students, all of whom graduated from Augustana in STEM majors. The ACSS program also benefited by developing alongside institutional initiatives to provide high impact educational experiences in the form of research opportunities, enhanced career mentoring and advising, and community-building activities. Upon entering the ACSS program, all participants were enrolled in a set of paired courses (a.k.a. a learning community), which included a one-credit seminar course called Becoming Biologists and a three-credit English composition course. This learning community emphasized acclimation to the Augustana community, becoming a proper scientist, and career exploration and preparation. Students made personal contact with representatives of Augustana’s career center, called Careers, Opportunities, Research and Exploration (CORE). Students also contributed to an authentic research experience that developed and then tested a biological assay for biofilm production. In subsequent years, nineteen ACSS students participated in optional research opportunities arranged through the ACSS program. All ACSS students participated in a required senior inquiry experience related to their STEM major. ACSS students were encouraged to visit CORE throughout their academic career. Twenty-five of thirty-six students were assisted by CORE personnel in finding shadowing, research and/or internship experiences, and/or assisted in finding employment opportunities or in completing graduate school applications. In conclusion, the success of the Augustana College Science Scholars program was strongly influenced by a campus culture that shared the same objectives as the ACSS program. Numerous campus organizations were recruited for the ACSS program (e.g., Admissions, Financial Assistance, CORE, Office of Student Services). Experiences already integrated into the academic program of all Augustana students were utilized, which included an enhanced advising experience and required courses for the major.
